DOC.HEAD: Record Cold Continues, Snow Across Northern States

Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 4th to UPDATE with weather deaths, Mich. cold; INSERTS 4 grafs after the 9th graf previous, ``Freeezing rain,'' to update with stranded travelers, Ark. conditions; And Inserts 2 grafs after the 16th previous, ``A 200-mile,'' with Missouri River ice.
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures hit record lows Tuesday from the western Plains to the East Coast, including one at 26 below zero, and light snow fell across the Ohio Valley, the Great Lakes and the Northwest. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 35 degrees below zero at Bismarck, N.D., not a record. By noon, temperatures over much of the upper Mississippi Valley and northern Plains had not risen above zero. In stark contrast, southern Florida had record warmth in the upper 80s. Since Friday, at least 38 deaths have been blamed on the weather, including traffic deaths on slippery roads and hypothermia. Michigan outreach centers pleaded for warm clothes to give to help the needy stave off the unusual cold. The average mean temperature in Michigan for the first 18 days of December was 14.1 degrees, far below the month's norm of 23.5 degrees. ``I don't recall a December being quite this cold,'' Detroit police Sgt. George Anthony said Tuesday as he leafed through reports about victims of hypothermia. Two freezing deaths have been confirmed in Wayne County and at least three others are believed to be hypothermia. An inch or more of snow covered much of the nation north of a line from east-central Virginia across north-central Tennessee, northern Arkansas, southern Colorado and northwestern Utah to northwestern Idaho, the National Weather Service said. At midday, snow fell over western New York state, much of the western half of Pennsylvania, eastern and northern Ohio, West Virginia, much of Virginia, eastern Kentucky, Michigan, Montana, Idaho, western Wyoming and eastern Washington state. There were no reports of measurable snowfall during the six hours up to 1 p.m. EST, except in northwestern Indiana, where Westville had 5 inches of new snow by noon, the weather service said. Up to 4 inches fell early in the day in Illinois. A winter storm warning, in effect into Wednesday, was posted over northwestern Montana. Freezing rain fell from northeastern Texas across northern Louisiana and southern Arkansas, and over eastern Tennessee, much of North and South Carolina and northeastern Georgia, where the accumulating ice caused scattered power outages and glazed highways. More than 100 motorists stranded overnight at Hope, Ark., by ice on Interstate 30 were able to get back on the road Tuesday. ``We escorted about 104 people to the Community Center last night, starting around 9 p.m. and finishing at about one this morning,'' Hope Police Chief Richard Thomas said. In addition, officials said hotels in the area were full while other motorists spent the night in their vehicles. ``Wal-Mart's parking lot was full of 18-wheelers,'' Thomas said. Some 70 school districts across Arkansas remained closed Tuesday because of the inclement weather. State office workers were under the state's inclement weather policy, which gives non-essential administrative workers until 10 a.m. to arrive without being deducted leave time. Many northern Georgia counties kept their schools closed, although most Atlanta area schools reopened after being closed Monday. Officials in Griffin, Ga., said ice brought tree limbs down on power lines there, cutting electricity to large sections of the city for as long as two hours. Ice on roads was blamed for accidents around metropolitan Atlanta and Athens, and police blocked off several interstate highway ramps that were littered with cars and trucks unable to cross slick spots. Treacherous driving conditions in North Carolina caused at least one death and scores of traffic accidents, and dozens of schools and business closed. Rain fell from the remainder of Georgia into northern Florida and northern Alabama, and was scattered along the Gulf of Mexico coast. In the mountains of southeastern Wyoming, wind blew at 50 to 60 mph near Arlington and near Vedauwoo. A 200-mile stretch of the Mississippi River, from St. Louis to Cairo, Ill., was closed to barge traffic by ice and low water, the U.S. Coast Guard said. About 60 percent of the 195 miles of Missouri River north of Omaha, Neb., to the Gavins Point Dam was frozen over Tuesday, forming ice jams that reduced the amount of water flowing downstream to towns and power plants. The river level was within one foot of the level at which some power plants would be unable to operate because their water intake systems would no longer work, said Chet Worm, chief of the reservoir regulation section of the Corps Missouri River District. Record low temperatures were 8 at Atlantic City, N.J.; 6 at Baltimore; 10 at Bridgeport, Conn.; 26 below zero at Dickinson, N.D.; 6 below at Elkins, W.Va.; 19 below at Grand Island, Neb.; 5 at Harrisburg, Pa.; 20 below at Lincoln, Neb.; 24 below at Norfolk, Neb.; 7 below at Wheat Ridge, Colo.; and 3 below at Youngstown, Ohio. But in Florida, Miami hit a record high of 85 and West Palm Beach reached a record 88. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 18 degrees below zero at Detroit Lakes and International Falls, Minn., to 87 at West Palm Beach.
